segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. William B. Harris, professor of chemical engineering at Texas A&M University.
Today's date is October 12, 1981.
Let's begin, Dr. Harris, by you telling us something about your early years in Loveland, Colorado.
You were born there in 1919.
Well, Loveland, Colorado is probably the best part of the world to be born in and raised as a boy because it's the so-called gateway to Estes Park or the Rocky Mountain National Park.
It's 50 miles north of Denver.
And I went to school, grade school and high school in Loveland.
In 1933, 37, I should say, I went to the University of Colorado at Boulder.
What was your father's occupation?
He was a retired farmer who had gone into the insurance business and actually had done pretty good as a farmer and the insurance was something to keep him out of the house, I believe.
How did he happen to settle in Colorado?
My folks were all pioneers, I guess.
The type that crossed the prairies and settled the west.
For example, a first irrigation ditch in Colorado was dug and created by my grandfather.
Where did your grandfather immigrate?
He came from Missouri, northern Arkansas.
I'm not exactly sure, but it was part of the throes of the aftermath of the Civil War.
I know that at one time they had a lot of land with a lot of slaves and this all got torn up so most of the family moved to Colorado.
A rather interesting story there.
My grandfather went to Colorado with a covered wagon and the woman he married was with another covered wagon train.
The two of them met in what is now Denver.
At that time it was Arvada.
white spot on the river.
What was that?
Arvada, Colorado.
It was just a little bit.
A-B-A A-R-V-A-D-A It's now a suburb of Denver.
Anyhow, my grandmother was out in the middle of the road with her bloomers tucked up out of the river, washing clothes.
Granddad apparently rode out on his horse out there to look at her and announced to the world he was going to marry her, which they eventually did.
I used to get a lot of interesting stories about the Wild West that I, the pioneers that I wish I could remember.
Some of them are absolutely fascinating.
People had a different attitude toward life then than they do now, that's for sure.
I had a great uncle who put the first dam across the big Thompson River for irrigation, which is still there and still being used.
with a home supply ditch corporation.
In any event, we went to 37, graduated from high school, and went to the university.
What year did you graduate?
And went to the University of Colorado to take chemical engineering.
Chemical engineering was not too well known at that time.
But I'd had chemistry in high school, which was great fun because we were allowed to make firecrackers and various other things, which they no longer allow students to do.
And since I liked mechanisms in general, chem engineering sounded like a good thing to go into.
This, of course, was a four-year curriculum.
And due course, we graduated and went to work at Buffalo, New York,
with the National Aniline Division of Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation.
What was that again?
National Aniline Division of Allied Chemical and Aniline.
A-N-I-L-I-N-E.
This is a dye stuff corporation.
And dye stuffs are rather complex organic chemistry.
It's rather interesting in those days most of the

organic chemical industry was based upon coal and then of course switched over into what we call petrochemicals made from petroleum and now we're in the process of switching back to sort of where I started out, benzene and things like this from coal again.
This was a rather interesting job.
I started out in production for about a year and apparently made such a pest of myself they moved me over into the research department which is in some ways
rather disastrous since everybody else had a PhD in chemistry and it wasn't quite the place for a BS chemical engineer.

Turned out it was very good, however, because they had a policy there that for every new process that was developed by the research department, it was taken out and demonstrated in the plant before the production people were given the progen.
This is something that does take chem engineering, so I ended up doing much of the chem engineering for the entire research department, which was a great experience.
The fact is, I guess I got involved in about every chemical reaction that's labeled except the Grenard reaction.
But this would be involved, they'd call me in and say, Dr. So-and-so's got a process that uses 35 ether extractions, which is impractical and also can't use ether in the plant.
Harris take it out of the plant and make it, which is chem engineering rather than basic research in chemistry.
And so I enjoyed it quite a bit.
I did not like Buffalo very well.
How long were you there?
I was there six years.
What happened is the war broke out in 1941 and of course the war disrupted everything.
I got shifted off into this research program, and one of the things I was working on was what they call Atabrin, or Quinacrin, which is an anti-malarial drug.
Can you spell those?
A-T-A-B-R-I-N, and another name for it is Quinacrin, Q-U-I-N, Q-U-I-N-E, Quinacrin.
I think that's right.
It's been a while.

Anyhow, the Japanese had taken over all the South Sea islands where the quinine was produced, and it was impossible for us to invade the South Sea islands and conduct any kind of a war program without quinine.
So someone captured some German soldiers in North Africa.
The Germans, being very methodical, had pre-planned all this, and they had developed an anti-malarial that worked somewhat similar to quinine.
And so they brought some of the tablets back, and we were given the job of mass producing this for our armed forces.
As a result, I never did serve in the armed forces.
I spent my time working with this adamant, which incidentally is a very yellow material, and after you work with it a while, you begin to look like you were made of yellow rather than white.
met my wife in Buffalo, New York, which was one of the pluses of the area.
They also had us, of course, frozen into our jobs as well as frozen into our salaries, so that the first six years of my life, as far as increasing my salary is concerned, were pretty non-productive.
It turned out that if you were a union man, a laborer,
You could get periodic raises, but if you were on salary, you were frozen at whatever salary you had.
So just about every supervisor in the plant was making less money than the most menial of workers, which is some kind of a commentary on politics in general.
I never did like Buffalo simply because it's too dang cold.
The winter lasts approximately nine months, and the summer a couple of days type of thing to me.

So as soon as the war was over and I had the opportunity, I moved to Benson, Arizona, which is about as far from snow and cold as you can get, and went to work with the Apache Powder Company of Benson, Arizona.
What year was this?
This would be in 1946.
But you worked in Buffalo all through the war?
All through the war.
You see, you couldn't change your job then.
And as soon as I could get out of Buffalo, I got out.
How did your wife feel about leaving?
She didn't much care for it.
For leaving it?
For leaving it.
Now she will kind of grin and say it was probably the best thing we've ever done, but at the time it was quite a strain on things, I'll have to admit that.
Particularly going as far as Arizona, which got her away from her parents a long distance and homesick, and a total change.
Around Buffalo it was very green and verdant, and the Arizona desert is just the opposite.
Arizona is a pretty good place for a man to live.
There's a lot of hunting and rough country to play in, but for women, there's not even, people in Benson, which is only 900 people in the town, 960, didn't even grow grass in their yards.
It was all sand and it was kind of a desolate area, so she never did like it very well.
I enjoyed it because I had a very good job.
I went there as a research engineer, chemist.
In those days, chemists in the
chem engineers weren't as well differentiated as now.
And after being there about three and a half years, the company decided to about triple its size.
And this whole task was on my shoulders, which was a very interesting thing.
I'd never gotten involved in construction and design before like that.
I designed the buildings.
I hired the crew.
I laid out narrow gauge railroads and did all kinds of things that I would never have thought as a chem engineer I would ever be doing.
And in the midst of all this, I got promoted to the title of technical supervisor for the company.
So I was in charge of their engineering and development, the product quality control program, customer relations, safety and health, which is a big thing in an explosives plant.
In general, anything that had any technical aspects to it was under my charge.
I enjoyed it.
It was a good job.
It was a small town, which I have always enjoyed.
My wife didn't like it, and the job was very demanding.
In those days, they didn't have what we call human engineering now.
The general idea was if you worked hard eight hours a day and didn't worry, someday you could be the boss and work 16 hours a day and have all the worry.
I was working usually from 70 to 80 hours a week, which means just about all your waking time.
But when you enjoy it, this is not particularly bad.
It's bad for your family.
This was brought home to me very much because
One Sunday, I was out at the plant with the plant manager.
We were going over a bunch of blueprints by ourselves, a big empty office building, of course.
And the PX board started buzzing, so I plugged it in.
And it was Stanford University calling the plant manager to tell him that his son had just been found in the automobile with an exhaust hose stuck into the window and, of course, was dead by suicide.
This was of course a big tragedy and the plant manager jumped in the company car that we had there and took off immediately and left me there to call my wife to come and get me.
So I had about a half hour of thinking before my wife got there.
And I could pretty well perceive why this poor kid had committed suicide because his dad had been too busy all the time to really be much of a father.
And since he had the best job in town, his mother felt like she was sort of the queen bee of the society and didn't have much time either.
So they had great expectations for the boy, but he was just a sort of an average kid and couldn't live up to these expectations.
Then I got to thinking I had a son who was about three years old, about two and a half perhaps, that I hadn't seen awake for at least five to six weeks.
You know, you just look in the door and see them laying there, and I got to thinking, that's pretty dumb.

By the time my wife got out to the plant, I told her I was going to quit, figuring that she'd probably raise the roof one way or another, and all she did was say, great, let's move back where my folks live.
I told her no.
I was going to find a job that was dignified, that I didn't have to be ashamed of.
It was in a relatively good climate.
a cultural place that had things to do and good schools for children.

But I'll be damned if I was going to spend the rest of my life trying to become a plant manager or president of the company because it's just there were too many things you had to sacrifice at that time at least in order to have that type of work.
So in casting about, it looked like a university environment here at College Station was just about the best thing that would fit that mold.
Certainly a nice climate.
a job that you don't have to be ashamed of, a cultural place, good schools, and close enough to Buffalo that you can make it once or twice a year, which is enough to visit in-laws generally anyhow.
So I came here to work initially as a research engineer with the Cotton Seed Products Research Laboratory, which was part of the TEAS
at that time, and that was in 1953.
So I stayed approximately six, six and a half years at Apache Powder and then moved here.
Of course, I've been here ever since.
The Cotton Seed Products Research Laboratory at that time concentrated entirely on, or almost entirely on, cotton seed problems.
There were about 500 cotton seed oil mills
in the state at that time.
It was a big industry and appropriate that the college conduct research in this area.
It was funded by a separate granting from the Cotton Research Committee, which was a division of the state legislature.
In the process of this work, people, myself and others at the, and prior to me actually too,

developed considerable improvements in the handling and processing of cottonseed which of course the idea is you get cottonseed oil which is a edible made into margarine or cooking oil and lint and holes and other products that are useful elsewhere.
We started working and
on solvent extraction of cottonseed oil, which was a better process than the hydraulic processes that had been employed.

One of the characteristics of this, though, it becomes more and more like a chemical engineering plant, which lends itself to all-year production rather than seasonal operation, and huge operations rather than comparatively small localized plants.

And I understand as a result of that now the number of oil mills in the state of Texas has dwindled to a small, a very small fraction of the roughly 400 or 500, about 500 that were here when I first came.

As a result, the oilseeds laboratory or cottonseed laboratory has gone through a progression of names and I think it's now called the Food and Protein Research Center as they've shifted into different areas.
as the need for research and the number of companies involved has become limited in the cottonseed industry of Texas by itself.
About 1958, we had a change in administration in Tees and the School of Engineering.
We got a new dean, Dr. Calhoun.
who came in with the concept that people who do research should teach, and particularly people that teach should do research.
Dr. Calhoun is now vice president of engineering and renewable resources.
So one day, rather unexpectedly, I got a phone call informing me that I was now also an associate
professor in the Chem Engineering Department.
Did you work in graduate programs?
No.
I hadn't even been inside a classroom since I got out in 1941, and all of a sudden I was going to teach a course the following Monday.

Kind of perturbed me, but the head of the department at that time, Dr. Lindsay, just sort of grinned and says, well, you'll find that you know a lot more than the students do, so you'll make out all right, which
which turned out to be a very true statement.
So I started teaching part-time for the chem engineering department and researching part-time then in the cotton seed products laboratory.
That was in 58.
This was in 58.
I found, as many people do once I got started in teaching, that this was a very fascinating occupation and one that I thoroughly enjoyed.
I had some problems.
When I came here, one of the conditions was that I would be allowed to go ahead and get an advanced degree.

And I had started on my master's program, but of course we have in the catalog rules against granting advanced degrees to people who are ranked as professors at the university, which is a perfectly understandable restriction.
And because of the salary I made as a research engineer, I had been classified as an associate professor, which meant that theoretically I wasn't supposed to get an advanced degree.
I was able to convince everybody that I'd already been started on this program and I should be allowed to finish, and so I got my master's of chemical engineering here at A&M in 1960.
I was blocked from going any further as far as getting an advanced degree here at A&M.
I could take all the graduate courses I wanted, but they were meaningless as far as applying to any kind of a degree program.
I proceeded to take graduate courses.
I got a whole armload of them, but primarily just, I guess, for my own edification because it did not enable me
move ahead as far as becoming a PhD was concerned.
So all during the 60s, I was working then under two hats for the cottonseed lab and for chem engineering department.
And gradually, 1960 or 61, I'd have to look it up now.
It's amazing how insignificant it is now and how important it was at the time.

But this didn't, I ran into some problems here because of course to get promotions within the organization here, particularly in the teaching area, you really ought to have something more than a master's degree.
And I felt that I needed to do something, but at the same time I was making such a salary that I couldn't afford to just take off and go somewhere and get a PhD and then hopefully return.
About 1969, the legislature passed a law permitting the colleges to fund sabbatical leaves.
So I immediately applied for a sabbatical leave, which was granted, to go ahead and study to get a PhD.
And my understanding, this was the only one that was granted for the, to go ahead and work on an advanced degree at the
The people who put this program together decided one of the very first rules was that no one would be given a sabbatical to do this.
Dean Benson, however, was then in charge of the Engineering and Experiment Station, and he was able to convince whoever was involved that this would be an appropriate thing.
So I did get this sabbatical leave.
So in 69, I went to the Colorado State University.
Fort Collins, Colorado.
Now, one of my reasons, of course, was I enjoyed Colorado when I was young, and I wanted to get back into that area as much as possible.
But the main reason was I had gotten into a very, very interesting subject in the cottonseed research work, which was the cooling of cottonseed.
These piles of cottonseed cost well over a million dollars.
And of course, they're organic and subject to mold and spoilage.
So the way they control this is pulling air
through the pile of seed to a collecting duct system on the bottom of the pile and air cools the seed and dries it out so that it stays without degradation.
The equations for this kind of thing though is a typical fluid flow through porous media type of thing.
It's the same as you have there for underground oil reservoirs or hydrology
science of aquifers.
It turns out that Colorado State University is probably one of the best places in the world to study fluid flow through porous media.
And I kind of struck a deal with the agricultural engineering department there.

who, probably agricultural engineers, have been more interested in fluid flow through porous media for longer, I guess, than the petroleum people, because, of course, this is involved in the movement of moisture to the plants, and particularly involved in irrigation, which Colorado is a great irrigated area.
So, since that was my interest, I went to the ag engineering department rather than through a normal chemical engineering department somewhere else.
And I'm kind of proud of this because I spent one year at Colorado and did get my PhD, which is probably I guess a world record for getting a PhD.
One reason I was able to do this though is that they allowed me to use the research that I had been doing for the cotton seed products laboratory as the basis of my thesis.
So mainly the problem was getting the
course credits out of the way.
Unfortunately, only 12 hours of my courses here could be transferred and the rest of it I had to take at location in Colorado.
While I was in Colorado, they had a reorganization of the cottonseed products research laboratory and had kind of come to the conclusion that this split work between
two departments was not very, really the best way of handling things.
And apparently in my absence there was a big discussion as to whether I would go back and work full time for the cottonseed lab or full time for the chem engineering department.
And I don't know exactly just how, what all happened, but I was informed while I was gone that when I came back I would be a full time employee of the chem engineering department.
So since then, I have not been active in the cottonseed research or food proteins research area.
I think it was 1973 before I finally got my thesis approved and my dissertation approved and got my actual degree from Colorado State.
Shortly thereafter, I was promoted to full professor in the Department of Chem Engineering, which I've been since, of course.

I think our department has been a very good department because it has a good blend of people who are what I would call very theoretical, which you need in an academic area, and people who are very practical or engineering-oriented, which I consider myself to be.
so that we all sort of complement each other.
My research program has been for quite some time.
We started back in 1963.
I worked for about six months temporarily for and with Dr. Davison of the Chem Engineering Department on water desalination.
And in the process of working on that, we got involved in solar energy.
So when I became full time in the chemical engineering department, Dr. Davison and I continued working together on the solar energy research program.
In the course of this, we came across what we think is a very, very, very worthwhile idea as far as solar energy is concerned.
We kind of think at this moment that we were probably 10 or 15 years ahead of our time.
But basically the problem with heating buildings with solar energy is that you want to heat buildings in the wintertime and you want to therefore collect the sun during the wintertime.
But unfortunately the wintertime is winter because we don't have much sunshine.
The real time to collect solar energy is the summer or all year round and then use this energy during the winter.
So obviously one of the problems would be

figure out how you could store solar energy for six months or longer periods without losing it and we came up with a very very useful concept which we call the solitaire system actually we came up with this concept quite some time before we actually got to
any program going in chem engineering here, I mean in solar work here at the department.

Basically what we proposed doing was pumping water from an underground aquifer, from a well in other words, particularly during the summer but all year long really, running it through solar heaters where the water would get hot and then take this hot water and pump it down another well back into the aquifer.
And the concept is that the aquifer, this underground water-filled strata, is in essence a very, very cheap insulated mammoth storage tank.
In other words, the ground is a very good insulator.

So the idea is you store the hot water, and then when winter comes, you pump the hot water out from under the ground around the various buildings like we have here on the campus, which all the buildings are heated by hot water being pumped from the powerhouses.

This has a lot of merit, and besides the fact that you collect the energy all year round, you no longer have your capital that you've put into the solar heaters just sitting idle most of the year and used only during the winter.
And since the solar energy business is totally capital intensive, this is very important.
But the solar heaters operated during the summertime are much more efficient than during the winter.

because in the winter solar heaters are surrounded by ice cold air and they lose a good share of their energy to the surrounding air whereas in the summer they are surrounded by much warmer air and their efficiency is therefore better.

So not only do you use your capital all year round you can collect about five times as much energy per square foot of heater or per dollar is worth a heater but the heaters are more efficient and since this kind of a system would use a very large solar heating
array, you get away from the very expensive idea of putting very small heaters custom made and custom installed on each building.
It becomes a utility type system.
It also became rather apparent in this that if you can store hot water underground, you can store cold water.
So the analog is to take the pump water out from under the aquifer during the winter, spray it into the air,
a spray pond, get it close to freezing using the natural coolness of the winter and store cold water.
And then of course in the summer you would air condition your buildings just as they're done here again on the campus by pumping chilled water from a central source to the various buildings.
This, if you look at it, is economically a very, very, very attractive way of getting air conditioning.
So we had this scheme called the Solitaire Scheme which appears to be economic and answer and solve the problems that keep solar energy from being widely used.
It had one trouble.
You can't do it on a small scale.
You can't store a small quantity of water anywhere.
It has to be a large quantity stored underground and therefore it becomes a rather expensive
installation.
It's fine for say air conditioning a campus but it wouldn't work at all for air conditioning a home.
Nor can you actually study it in the laboratory.
There's no way you can build a sand pile or something and put a little water in it and expect it to stay hot until next summer.
So even though you can model and the work that I've done

Colorado State on my PhD was in the area of aquifer flow through porous media you can model and you can show in a mathematical sense exactly what's going to happen but since it costs roughly a million dollars or so to put one of these systems in we haven't been able to find anyone with a million dollars yet everybody that has the money that looks at it and says it's a great idea show me one that's working
And of course, there is none working.
So that has been a problem.
We did get a small grant from the Department of Energy to study the storage of cold water, which we did out on the river bottom farm.

We knew that we wouldn't be able to store the water because that was a 65 foot deep aquifer, which is almost like a sandbar out in the river, and a considerable amount of water movement through that type of a formation.
But at least we were able to demonstrate that the system was feasible.

As a matter of fact, we put down out of a pond that was only 50 foot by 100 foot over 10 million gallons of ice cold water underground, which means that on a good cold night in the winter here, this 50 by 100 foot pond was approximately a 200 ton air conditioner, where the only
power cost was for the cost of spraying the water into the spray.
So you can see it has a great advantage over refrigeration because you're using the natural cold air to do the cooling.
This particular cooling thing is being tried, this will be tried this winter in a shopping center in Tuscogee, Alabama.
Where?
K-O-G-E-E.
I think it's the capital of Alabama.
Anyhow, it's where the University of Alabama is located.
We're a little bit concerned because we don't know what kind of an aquifer they have.
Tuscaloosa.
Yeah, Tuscaloosa.
I'm sorry.
Tuscogee, that's Florida, isn't it?
I think you were getting Tuscaloosa and Tuskegee.
Okay, all right.
But anyhow...
If they have a good aquifer, we've seen blueprints of the surface installation.
It looks like they'll be able to use this system to good advantage.
And we hope that once somebody has one that they can deep walk up to and kick, that other entrepreneurs then won't be so reluctant to put their money in.
Because this particular concept, as Department of Energy have estimated,
that after it started, within about 10 years, it should save about $12 billion worth of oil per year.
We think their estimate for the number of installations is low, but the profit at each installation is possibly a little bit high.
But my feeling would be, if the idea catches on, that it should save considerably more than $12 billion.
We almost got the Kennedy International Airport air conditioned with this system,
They put so many restrictions about spraying water into the air, which might cause fog, which might create hazardous conditions and so forth.
They never were able to get it materialized.
The other area we've been working in is in the alternative energy of automotive fuels.
We had noticed in 1973 that the price of methanol, methyl alcohol,
It dropped so low that it, on paper at least, would be cheaper to use alcohol as an automotive fuel than gasoline.
This was true, but only for a momentary aberration of the market.
But it was enough to get us interested in alcohol fuels.
And at about the same time, the oil embargo hit, which indicated that the country may not
be able to enjoy all the petroleum that it's been used to, and there'd be severe dislocations.

And it became apparent to most thinking people, I think, that we're going to have to go to coal, of which we have approximately a fifth or fourth of all the world's resources, as our energy source, rather than petroleum.
And we began to think that we perceived some tunnel vision on the people.
that when something like this, that cars run on gasoline, gasoline can be made from coal.
So when the price is right, this is what we will do.
As chem engineers and looking at the various processes, we find two things.
First, that the making methanol from coal will probably always be less expensive than making gasoline just by nature of the process.
Secondly,

The technique or the technology for making methanol from coal is firmly established, whereas the gasoline from coal processes are very iffy and technically need a great deal of work before they really are worked out to the point that they ought to be used.
So our concept was that if cars can run on methanol, and if methanol is less expensive, we should start running our cars on methanol.

However, when we began looking into it, we found quotations such as one from Chevron, for example, where they said they had spent hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars studying methanol as an automotive fuel.
And that concluded it would never be a suitable fuel for automotive use.
It turns out the reason for this is that the alcohol takes about eight times as much.
Well, there was another form of tunnel vision, really.

which went something like this gasoline is a liquid you feed gasoline through a carburetor alcohol is a liquid obviously you should feed it through a carburetor the problem is this doesn't work because alcohol takes eight times as much heat to vaporize as does gasoline and your car just cannot furnish this amount of heat so that when you
try to run a carbureted alcohol car while the car really will run rather well.
At the same time, you're spraying a mist or a fog into your cylinders rather than a vaporized fuel.
And this has a number of problems.
First, it makes it very difficult to start the car.
An alcohol carbureted car is generally, without help, won't start below 50 Fahrenheit.
But some of these droplets don't burn.
They get on the walls of the cylinder.
where they tend to wash the lubricant off of the cylinder.
And as a result, you get enhanced wear.

Other problems also, some of the droplets get down into the crank case where they precipitate the stream wear additives that are in the oil and otherwise react with the oil so that the film strength of the oil is cut about 50%.
means it's no longer as good a lubricant as it was.
So you have additional problems.
And lastly, methyl alcohol in the crankcase will form formic acid, which is corrosive and detrimental to the engine.
So looking at all of these things, we decided that the route to go would be to vaporize the alcohol and feed that into the engine rather than carburet liquid into the engine, which
presumably putting in vapor will get rid of all these wear problems.
And it does one other thing.
It enables us to make a dual fuel vehicle, which will run either on gasoline or on alcohol vapor.
In other words, the vapor system can be superimposed on any given alcohol engine.
We started working on this, and have been working pretty steadily on it for the last several years.
And what we think we have is a car that is perfectly drivable,
acceptable that runs on either gasoline or alcohol with no change in drivability that's noticeable.
And so we think we have at the moment probably the only viable economic and acceptable alternative to letting the price of gasoline continue to rise with the rise in OPEC prices
simply because an alternative now does exist to make methyl alcohol and use it as a fuel.
Well, methanol right now is selling for 77 cents, which is just about competitive with gasoline.

But it's right now being made from natural gas, which is going up very rapidly in price and will go up much faster, I presume, as soon as they decontrol the price because natural gas has been held at an artificially low price for many years for political purposes.
And we've been talking to various people, the continental oil people, Conoco.
We've just converted two cars for them, their use.
They are interested in methanol, unlike quite a few of the other oil companies, because they own Consolidated Coal Company, who owns the largest block of coal of any one company.
They tell us that they can make, in 1980 dollars, methanol at the plant for 38 cents a gallon.
Of course, you have to add your markups to that.
Well, they haven't built those plants.
They are planning to build, or were planning to build, five of them.

Of course, they've just been merged with DuPont, which may change the entire spectrum there, because DuPont has been a producer of chemical methanol for years, and it's been a very profitable market for them.
And if anyone were to make a fuel-sized plant, just one plant,
talking in this small refinery, would be bigger than all of the alcohol plants that are now being produced, or the chemical market would just sort of evaporate or get submerged.
We think, however, that it is the only alternative that exists at the moment, and we think it's a very good one.
And what we anticipate is that the country may very well slide into what I would call the methanol economy, where at least our automotive industry
vehicles and so forth will be running on methyl alcohol.
When do you think that might occur?
It will take quite a while because we have a tremendous sized gasoline inventory of cars and stations and refineries and so forth.
But I think it may happen sooner than you might think.
The Ford Motor Company people were here just about a month ago and they informed us, we've been

dealing with them for quite a few years, and they've been kind of down on our alcohol bet for quite a while, but they informed us that it's now their corporate opinion that the fuel of the future may very well be methanol.

Apparently this is because the oil companies seem to, by and large, all be changing their tune and taking a real serious look at methanol now, and have all been to the Ford company to see if they think cars will indeed be able to run on methanol.
We think the system is a very useful system.
It is, of course, the university has a patent posture in the system we devised.
We kind of hope that eventually the university and the rest of us can all make some money out of this, but time will tell as far as that is concerned.
What we have is a system that really is a kit that will mount on a car and allow it to be used for either alcohol or gasoline.
Now, down the road, I would anticipate cars that run only on methanol, but we think it would be at least 20 years before we could switch over
from one fuel to another.
You can't just say on some set date everybody starts driving on methanol.
It would take many, many years to build even the plants to produce that much fuel.

And if you have to pay $10,000 for a car, I don't think very many people would like a car that ran only on alcohol and they had to stay within 100 or 200 miles or something like that of their home base.
So we think a dual fuel car at this moment in time is essential and it may
may turn out to be the best route to go anyhow.

We have licensed the, well I guess the best way of saying it is we have sold options to license this system in Canada and in the Netherlands, and we're having a lot of fun talking to all kinds of people from all over the world.
I've met people I would never have met before in my life.
For example, we've had three vice presidents of Exxon, three vice presidents of Shell, one vice president of General Motors, one vice president of Ford, president and vice...
